Award.AwardTitle: Immunomodulatory ultrathin coatings for pancreatic islet transplantation
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1306110 PI: Kharlampieva, Eugenia ORG: University of Alabama-Birmingham

Title: Immunomodulatory Ultrathin Multilayer Coatings for Pancreatic Islet Transplantation

Technical: Although transplantation of pancreatic islet cells has emerged as a promising treatment for Type 1 diabetes, its clinical application remains limited due to adverse effects of immunosuppression and declining allograft function. To overcome these hurdles, a preclinical approach to protect isolated islets and to modulate autoimmune responses in Type 1 diabetes is proposed. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel cytoprotective coatings with controlled immunomodulatory and inflammatory responses, and to gain insight into the fundamental mechanism of the coating activity to preserve islet viability and function. These coatings will be designed through layer-by-layer hydrogen-bonded assembly of cytocompatible macromolecules with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory characteristics. The objectives of the proposed study are as follows: (1) Synthesize ultrathin coating materials with a layer-by-layer hydrogen-bonded assembly approach. A series of novel functional copolymers with antioxidant metalloporphyrin modality will be synthesized and self-assembled through hydrogen-bonding interactions. (2) Define the immunomodulatory effects of 'islet-free' coatings in vitro. A novel polymer coating with advanced antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity will be obtained. The coatings are adaptable and can be further modified to facilitate non-invasive imaging. (3) Evaluate the immunomodulatory effects of 'on-islet' coating in response to immune challenges in vitro. These efforts will establish fundamental correlations with biomaterial properties and islet function, and provide transformative knowledge for modification of other living cell types in a rapid and efficient manner.

Non-Technical: The proposed research presents new opportunities for the development of novel cytoprotective materials to be used for basic research applications as well as a cell-based transplantation therapy for diabetic recipients. Our proposal is particularly timely since current islet encapsulation systems are challenging for transplantations due to high cytotoxicity and the requirement for large injection volumes. The design of novel immunoprotective materials will open new prospects for developing biomaterials with unique characteristics having applications in various bio-related areas such as bioengineering and tissue engineering. The educational objective of this project is to develop a discovery-driven, multidisciplinary biomaterials/polymer sciences program at UAB to promote diversity from the high school through graduate-level. The PI is currently developing a polymer science program at UAB with a specific focus on biomaterials at the B.S. and Ph.D. levels. High school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including underrepresented minorities, will be trained in modern aspects of biopolymer science including state-of-the-art synthetic and analytical methods, and will take part in intensive multidisciplinary collaborations throughout and beyond UAB. The proposed activities will develop interdisciplinary collaborative research between the Departments of Chemistry, Surgery, and Microbiology. These collaborative efforts will stimulate awareness of the needs of the UAB biomedical research community for specialized polymer-based biomaterials as novel platforms for cell transplantation therapy. The results will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at national and international scientific conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though pancreatic islet transplantation has emerged as a promising treatment for Type 1 diabetes, its clinical application remains limited due to adverse effects of immunosuppression and declining allograft function.  To overcome these complications, we have developed novel cytoprotective conformal polymeric coatings with controlled immunomodulatory and inflammatory responses, and gained into the fundamental mechanism of the coating activity.

Intellectual Merit

We have synthesized nanothin multilayer coatings of alternative layers of a natural polyphenol, tannic acid (TA), and hydrophilic non-ionic and biocompatible macromolecules of poly(N-vinypyrrolidone) (PVPON) or poly(N-vinylcaprolactam) (PVCL) via hydrogen-bonded interactions.  We have developed RAFT synthesis and produced well-controlled PVCL and PVPON homopolymers and their block copolymers with well-defined molecular weights and compositions.  These  block copolymer  assemble at the physiological conditions into supramolecular structures which allows for embedding functional molecules that can ameliorate destruction of insulin-producing beta-cells if introduced within the protective coating around pancreatic islets.  We have identified the critical conditions for chemical stability of TA solutions and TA/PVPON or TA/PVCL complexes relevant in islet encapsulation process and the conditions affecting the multilayers thickness and diffusion of small molecules.  We  have also demonstrated the importance of TA/PVPON  biomaterials as a novel islet encapsulation nanothin coating to mediate immunosuppression by blunting proinflammatory cytokine and chemokine expression.  Our results show that the TA-based coatings display efficient antioxidant and immunomodulatory properties by scavenging free radicals and suppressing the synthesis of interferon-gamma and tissue necrosis factor-alfa proinflammatory molecules and that dissipation of radical oxygen species (ROS) synthesis diminishes diabetogenic T-cell responses via dampening a redox-dependent signaling pathway.  Moreover, autoreactive T cell migration is impaired with TA/PVPON multilayers due to suppressing proinflammatory chemokine synthesis.  In addition to decreasing proinflammatory activation of macrophage immune cells, the encapsulation of murine islets with TA/PVPON was found immunoprotective and efficient in preventing Th1 effector cell responses involved in destroying pancreatic islets.  Overall, our studies demonstrate that this polyphenolic coating applied to islet surfaces could function as an immunoprotective “shield” in the presence of autoreactive immune cells and therefore represent a highly promising immunomodulatory biomaterial for islet transplantation.  Our discoveries should have a positive impact on the wide application of the nanotechnology in cell surface engineering and biomaterials field.

Broader Impacts

The proposed research became a ground for the development of novel biologically active nano-layered materials which are used for basic research applications as well as a cell-based transplantation therapy for recipients with type 1 diabetes.   Transplantation of islets protected by polyphenol-containing nanothin coatings may decrease the risk of xeno- and allograft rejection due to the attenuation of oxidative stress and synthesis of proinflamatory molecules, enable the development of novel immunotherapies and ultimately, enable Type 1 diabetics a lifestyle independent of exogenous insulin administration.  On the other hand, the results from our work should help develop new autoimmune therapies which are currently limited due to non-specific immunosuppressive agents that alter the ability of the immune system to handle autoreactive immune cells.  The multilayer polymer assembly has potential for clinical translation and application as the developed biomaterial coatings do not increase size or volume of the encapsulated islets and the approach can be easily automated for scalable outcome.  Collectively, these studies by defining the fundamental roles of oxidative stress, immune responses, beta-cell function, and polymer chemistry in islet transplantation produced the fundamental insights that can influence the novel design of therapeutic strategies to restore euglycemia and enhance islet transplantation to treat Type 1 Diabetes.

From the educational perspective, the project helped to develop a discovery-driven multidisciplinary biomaterials/polymer sciences program and enrich the existing polymer science B.S. and Ph.D. major programs at the UAB and promote diversity from the high school through graduate-level.  The project supported participation in the study of 9 graduate students with three of them graduated with PhD degrees in Polymer Chemistry, 12 undergraduates with 5 of them as paper co-authors and 3 of the continuing their graduate education at USA universities, and one high school student.  The students have been trained in modern aspects of biomaterials and polymer science including advanced synthetic and analytical methods and were involved in intensive multidisciplinary collaborations through and beyond UAB.  Thus, this project allowed the development of interdisciplinary collaborative research between the UAB Departments of Chemistry, Physics, Surgery, Microbiology (Immunology), Radiology, the Department of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolism, the Department of Cardiovascular Disease, the Southern Research Institute (Birmingham, AL), and the University of Alberta (Canada).  These collaborative efforts will continue to stimulate awareness to the needs of the UAB biomedical research community for specialized polymer-based biomaterials as novel platforms for cell transplantation therapy.  The results generated by this project were disseminated through ten peer-reviewed articles, two book chapters, a conference paper, and via 54 presentations given at national and international scientific conferences and two workshops. Our research  was highlighted on the Soft Matter back Cover and Advanced Healthcare Materials Frontispiece.
